Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Learning across the Expert-Novice Continuum: Cognition in the Geosciences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Two related research projects will investigate cognition across undergraduate geology majors, geology graduate students, and professional geologists. The field-based studies involve authentic tasks commonly used by students and professional geoscientists. Navigation (GPS) as well as cognitive (maps, audio logs, and debriefing interviews) data will allow the investigators to study complex natural problem solving. The laboratory studies involve a series of cognitive tasks that allow the investigation of working memory function, perceptual abilities, and the structuring of domain-specific content knowledge. The investigators expect to produce: (1) Valid and reliable methods for investigating field-based geologic cognition and navigation, which could allow for field-based cognitive data to be readily collected from large numbers of students enrolled in field courses; (2) New laboratory-based cognitive experiments that push the boundaries of existing knowledge about the cognitive processes underlying the learning and teaching of complex geoscience content, which will bridge the geoscience education and cognitive science literatures on STEM learning; and (3) A theoretical model for geocognition derived from empirical data that describes how cognitive processes manifest and change as students progress toward expertise, which will provide a foundation for research-based instructional design and teaching in the geosciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Purpose: Geologic maps are critical to finding fuel and mineral deposits, protecting groundwater and environmental resources, and keeping communities safe from hazards such as tsunami, volcanoes, and earthquakes. Mapping is a complex problem-solving activity in which the geologist must navigate through an unfamiliar terrain, identify surface rock outcrops, and mentally connect these outcrops underground. A better understanding of the thinking and skills involved in mapping will help to improve the education of future geoscientists. In this study, 67 geologists of varying experience from novice (college student) to expert (professional) completed a series of cognitive tests and a 1-day mapping project in the Rocky Mountains of Montana (Figure 1). Knowledge of geology, perception, memory, and spatial ability were tested, and results compared to levels of expertise, routes through the study area, actions and expressed thoughts during mapping, and the quality of each person’s final map (Figure 2). The project had two main goals: (1) to develop new techniques for studying how novices and experts think in complex, real-life situations, and (2) to gain a better understanding of what thinking and skills are important in mapping, and how these skills change with experience.

Intellectual Merit: To reach project goal (1), we developed a new method for integrating actions recorded on a head-mounted camera, spoken thoughts recorded on the camera microphone, and location in the field recorded by a Global Positioning System (GPS) unit. This method allows a researcher to integrate what a person sees, says, does, and where s/he goes in a very complex, outdoor problem-solving situation. Using this method and others to reach goal (2), we found that both novices and experts could be successful at mapping, but that success was achieved in different ways. Novices, who have lower knowledge of geology, used navigation strategies that allowed them to thoroughly cover the field area and rely on spatial ability to understand the surface distribution of rock types. They more often struggled to develop 3D mental models of how rocks connect underground. In contrast, experts use maps and photo images to develop initial mental models of the underground rocks, then planned routes to locations where they could test these models. These results were verified in a follow-up study of 77 geologists who drew routes through the field area on paper without being in the field area. Finally, in a second follow-up study of 172 geologists, we found that students, instructors, and professionals all value field education for geoscience college students mainly because they think that it enhances students’ knowledge and understanding, and allows students to interact with geological phenomena in its natural state.

Broader Impacts: This research contributes to ongoing conversations about the roles of knowledge and ability in science education. Consistent with studies in other disciplines, we have found that novices rely on spatial abilities to solve mapping problems, but experts bypass spatial ability and rely on prior knowledge instead. Recognition of this finding may make the geosciences more accessible to students with inherently lower spatial ability; these students might still be successful in the discipline if they develop a deeper, expert-like geological knowledge. Our work contributes to the field of cognitive science by demonstrating how to take research out of the laboratory setting and quite literally into the wild in order to study complex, real-life problem-solving.
